item.title: Geodesic complexity of the octahedron, and an algorithm for cut loci on convex polyhedra
item.description: arXiv:2508.19362v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The geodesic complexity of a length space $X$ quantifies the required number of case distinctions to continuously choose a shortest path connecting any given start and end point. We prove a local lower bound for the geodesic complexity of $X$ obtained by embedding simplices into $X\times X$. We additionally create and prove correctness of an algorithm to find cut loci on surfaces of convex polyhedra, as the structure of a space's cut loci is related to its geodesic complexity. We use these techniques to prove the geodesic complexity of an octahedron is four. Our method is inspired by earlier work of Recio-Mitter and Davis, and thus recovers their results on the geodesic complexity of the $n$-torus and the tetrahedron, respectively.
item.dc:creator: Florian Frick, Pranav Rajbhandari

item.title: On the Maximal Gaussian Perimeter of Convex Sets, Revisited
item.description: arXiv:2508.20079v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: We revisit Nazarov's construction of a convex set with nearly maximal Gaussian surface area and give an alternate analysis based on the notion of convex influence.
item.dc:creator: Shivam Nadimpalli, Caleb Pascale

item.title: Convex geometry over ordered hyperfields
item.description: arXiv:2301.12760v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: We initiate the study of convex geometry over ordered hyperfields. We define convex sets and halfspaces over ordered hyperfields, presenting structure theorems over hyperfields arising as quotients of fields. We prove hyperfield analogues of Helly, Radon and Carath\'eodory theorems. We also show that arbitrary convex sets can be separated via hemispaces. Comparing with classical convexity, we begin classifying hyperfields for which halfspace separation holds. In the process, we demonstrate many properties of ordered hyperfields, including a classification of stringent ordered hyperfields.
item.dc:creator: James Maxwell, Ben Smith

item.title: Improved bound on the dimension of vertical projections in the Heisenberg group via intersections
item.description: arXiv:2407.11475v2 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: It is shown that if $A$ is a Borel subset of the first Heisenberg group contained in either a vertical subgroup or a horizontal plane, then vertical projections almost surely do not decrease the Hausdorff dimension of $A$, with respect to the Kor\'anyi metric. For general Borel sets, it is shown that if $\dim A >2 $, then vertical projections of $A$ almost surely have dimension at least $2+\epsilon$, where $\epsilon$ depends only on the value of $\dim A$. This qualitatively improves the known bound in the general case when $2 < \dim A < 5/2+\delta$, for some small $\delta$. The horizontal case and the general case both rely on a variable coefficient local smoothing inequality.
item.dc:creator: Terence L. J. Harris

item.title: Quantum State Fidelity for Functional Neural Network Construction
item.description: arXiv:2508.16895v2 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: Neuroscientists face challenges in analyzing high-dimensional neural recording data of dense functional networks. Without ground-truth reference data, finding the best algorithm for recovering neurologically relevant networks remains an open question. We implemented hybrid quantum algorithms to construct functional networks and compared them with the results of documented classical techniques. We demonstrated that our quantum state fidelity methods can provide competitive alternatives to classical metrics by revealing distinct functional networks. Our results suggest that quantum computing offers a viable and potentially advantageous alternative for data-driven modeling in neuroscience, underscoring its broader applicability in high-dimensional graph inference and complex system analysis.
item.dc:creator: Skylar Chan, Wilson Smith, Kyla Gabriel
